awd_titl_txt: MRI Acquisition: Advanced Computing Infrastructure Driving long-tail Sciences
awd_abstract_narration:
ACIDS (Advanced Computing Infrastructure Driving Long-tail Sciences), supports and enables multidisciplinary research in LTS (Long Tail Science) projects that are not traditionally supported by large scale computing centers. The system whose acquisition is enabled by this award is expected to act as a catalyst for the regional advancement of LTS. The projects combine large collaborations and research programs requiring advanced computing infrastructure to work with the data and perform the latest analyses and simulations. The instrument supports the increase of knowledge in multiple domains since these machine learning methods are data hungry and computationally expensive.

The instrumentation advances scientific inquiries to improved antiviral developments, effective public policy decisions, efficient pathological review, and large-scale neuro-imaging data mining. The application of deep learning techniques, structural biology, neuroscience, public health evaluation, language translation, anomaly detection, etc., constitutes a common theme running through these projects. All participating faculty, staff, postdocs, and students across multiple centers and colleges will have access to ACIDS through collaborations and partnerships. Thus, training, outreach, and education will be supported in multiple application areas.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

inst.inst_name: Georgia State University Research Foundation, Inc.
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: GEORGIA STATE UNIVERSITY RESEARCH FOUNDATION INC

por.por_cntn:
The primary objectives of the MRI project encompassed the development of an advanced cyberinfrastructure tailored to support the distinctive requirements of researchers engaged in non-mainstream domains spanning disciplines such as neuroscience, business, public health, and policy studies. Our overarching goal was to establish a user-friendly, web-accessible environment that prioritizes both security and versatility. As a consequential outcome of the MRI awards, the Advanced Research Computing Technology and Innovation Core (ARCTIC) was instituted. ARCTIC resources are made available to the broader research community through research allocations with access granted via CILogon. Additionally, 20% of the MRI resources are shared with the Open Science Grid.

The establishment of ARCTIC not only successfully met the essential objective of providing crucial cyberinfrastructure for cutting-edge studies such as those involving Internet of Things (IoT), dynamic workload management with containers, and support for Machine Learning pipelines (MLOps), but it also played a pivotal role in fostering interdisciplinary collaboration among researchers. This initiative created a dynamic environment that actively encourages the exchange of ideas and expertise across diverse fields. Moreover, by design, ARCTIC significantly contributes to the expansion of research activities by offering a platform for innovative studies that leverages the essential cyberinfrastructure. It achieves this by facilitating access to resources, such as advanced computing technologies which are paramount for conducting groundbreaking research. The collaborative spirit embedded within ARCTIC extends beyond its technological components by promoting a culture of knowledge-sharing and cross-disciplinary engagement.

Furthermore, the project extended its impact by paving the way for new avenues in research activities. ARCTIC facilitates the dissemination of knowledge through the organization of annual SCD conferences and Scientific Computing Summer camps that catering to both undergraduate and high school students. This multifaceted approach underscores our commitment to advancing research, collaboration, and knowledge-sharing within the scientific community.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 01/22/2024
Modified by: Neranjan Edirisinghe Pathirannehe
